Row.Text: My name is James Misson. A Frenchman by birth, yes, but now I live a free life as the leader of Libertatia.
Ah, I do not think we have been introduced? I am Capitaine James Misson, of Libertatia.
We saw your sails, so I have come to greet the capitaine. James Misson of Libertatia, at your service.
We were not pirates, monsieur, but free men. Now our fate is in your hands.
Terrible. Libertatia was to be a land free of such brutality.
Bonjour.
Oh?
Oui.
Non.
It is impossible, mon capitaine.
Regards, mon capitaine. How may we help you?
There is no port handling charge, you may moor up as you wish. How are you?
Your sails in our ports are a terrible sign, as always.
Amid sinking your ships and taking your plunder... we must find time to enjoy the sea breeze, non?
We fight not under a black flag, but a pure blanc ensign. Ours is the cause of liberty!
Mon capitaine, I am pleased to see you. Welcome back to Libertatia.
Oui, it is a struggle against you, but in the end liberty will prevail. Why are you here?
I see you have set sail for war. Bon voyage, and good luck.
Are you attacking? I can not tell if these are soldiers, or scallywags!
You have brought your men to Libertatia. Why?
There will be no comfort for you, monsieur, when we are forced to confiscate your claims!
We do not treat territory like this in Libertatia. We expand only as we need.
Ah, monsieur, you are expanding once again. I will stop you.
Land is not to be bought and sold. No hedge may bound any man's particular property.
Your fleet is mighty and you lead good men, mon capitaine!
You have a treasury worthy of your greatness, mon capitaine! Travel safely on the high seas.
With so few cities, I do hope that at least they prosper. Your people are always welcome to become Liberi.
Where are your ships? Your army? You can not expect to live in peace with no defenders.
I have watched your hostile campaigns, and my concern only grows.
It is just a formality, mon capitaine, but shall we make a public Declaration of Friendship?
Our people are well adjusted to face this world together. If you agree, we can sign a Declaration of Friendship.
Our interests are aligned, non? A Declaration of Friendship will announce to the world that we stand as one.
Non, it is a little too soon. Patience will secure our friendship.
My apologies, capitaine, but on behalf of the Liberi I must say "non".
Mon capitaine, the scoundrels in {1_CivName} have insulted us once again. If you please, could you show your support in denouncing their behavior?
I find you to be quite disagreeable.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
Apologies, I must make my discontent with you known.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]([COLOR_WARNING_TEXT]They have publicly denounced us! NOTE: You are not at war.[ENDCOLOR])
Moi? I see. Carry on.
I do not know how we have offended you, but so be it.
You are friends with {1_CivName} as well? C'est magnifique.
Monsieur, I suggest you do not embrace {1_CivName} with such vigor. They differ from the barbarians in name only.
You have insulted our comrades in {1_CivName}. I do not wish to see our own relations soured.
Oui, {1_CivName} should worry us all with their behavior.
Your friends are our friends, mon capitaine. I have improved our relations with {1_CivName}.
Oui, we share your disgust with {1_CivName}. Let us share in your denunciation of them.
You and {1_CivName}, you are both scoundrels. We'll be keeping an eye out for your ships, monsieur.
The eyes of divine justice could never side with you. We will support {1_CivName} in the name of liberty.
I will not allow it, monsieur. I insist that you declare, if you are to attack us.
Ah, the horizon is littered with your sails. Attack if you will, but be warned.
Monsieur, I know your strategy. I will not allow this expansion.
Will you show some courtesy? We do not wish for a land dispute to become a conflict.
There are no hedges in Libertatia, no boundaries between property. We do not wish to stare at your borders.
Land is communal in Libertatia; is it not the same in your country? You claim a great deal.
{1_PlayerName:textkey} retains unarmed ships and undefended coasts. Mon capitaine, we must press our advantage now.
Mon capitaine, {1_PlayerName:textkey} look upon our nations with envious eyes. If we do not reduce their capacity for war, I believe they will come for us.
I bring news of a planned attack, mon capitaine. We must set sail against {1_PlayerName:textkey} at once!
{1_MinorCivName:textkey} do not wish to live under a flag of oppression. Life there is free, as it is in Libertatia.
Non, monsieur.
My apologies. We shall set sail for freedom elsewhere.
You may not simply declare ownership as you please, monsieur.
I couldn't help but notice how pathetic you are. And when I realized it I couldn't help but share.
Ah, it's always nice to see my favorite city-state again.
I'm really getting tired of seeing your face. My hope is that one day you'll just go away or something.
Ah, it's you. My apologies. Sometimes I get you mixed up with the barbarians I have to swat from time to time.
I thought you might like to know that your army is a little on the weak side. Better watch your back.
With an army so weak it's a surprise your empire hasn't succumb to a barbarian invasion.
Our words are backed with nuclear weapons!
It's a shame there are some leaders in this world who have their fun by picking on the weak. Don't you agree?
I can hear your people wailing in sorrow all the way over in my empire. If you don't do something soon they might just pack up and find a real civilization to live in.
With people so unhappy it's a shock to me that they'd keep you around as their leader.
It's come to my attention that your empire appears to be quite puny. Did you forget to expand your borders or are you just having a little trouble with that?
Travelers have told us that your empire's economy is in pretty sad shape. If you beg a little I might give you a hand. Okay, actually I won't.
What a sad sight... your empire is so uncultured. What do your citizens do all day, beat rocks together?
Rumor has it that your culture is so laughable that even the barbarians are shying away from your lands.
Even for us, there are some commodities we can not obtain on the high seas. May we make a trade?
No hedge should bound any man's particular property. I believe in these words, and offer them to you.
Monsieur, I hope you do not mean to insult me.
Mon capitaine, I think you would not give away your plunder for so little.
I do not know if this can be made agreeable.
Ah, then it is war? There is no other way?
Oui, I was expecting such an attack. Very well.
Ah, mon capitaine. How far you have fallen in my eyes.
En garde, then. I look forward to seeing your ships at the bottom of the ocean.
You are brave, mon capitaine, but you have pushed us too far. En garde!
Apologies, monsieur. We must set sail for your ships and coastlines!
I do not wish it, but we have no choice! Libertatia will not be cowed by your advance.
Monsieur, the land dispute has become intolerable. En garde!
Very well. Then shall we decide it on the high seas?
It is too early for peace, mon capitaine.
We will decide the time for peace, monsieur.
Ah, already you have second thoughts.
Our people are now plundering trade routes and burning their hedges. I worry the rest of the world will also succumb to the influence of your culture.
We are glad to see that your people are plundering trade routes and burning their hedges. The amazing works of our civilization are truly inspiring!
